prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for ending free friend rides in my car?
My friend always hops rides everywhere in my car. I fill up the tank and pick him up at his house and drop him back off safely at home. This past weekend he put 10 in gas because I forgot my purse home and yesterday he asked me back for it. He has ridden in my car hundreds of times without putting gas. Am I an asshole for saying find your way around in the future?
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for ending free rides for their friend. The situation is that the friend usually rides with the author, using the author's car, filling up gas, etc. This time, the author forgot their purse, so the friend put $10 in gas as a return. The author then told the friend to find their own way around.

The user thinks the author is wrong. I need to evaluate this. First, the friend has been riding for hundreds of times without contributing. The one time they did put in $10, the author cuts off rides. That seems a bit harsh. The friend might not be able to contribute every time, maybe due to forgetfulness or other reasons. The author is punishing them for one instance where they tried to repay, which could be seen as unfair. But on the other hand, the author might be frustrated that the friend never contributes except once. 

But the friend is trying to be helpful here. The author's response of cutting off all rides seems disproportionate. Ending the rides because of a one-time effort to repay might not be justified. The author could have been more understanding, maybe asked for regular contributions or set clear expectations. So I think the author is in the wrong here. Answer A.
